prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would. Calculate the temperature of the universe at an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, given that the cosmic microwave background radiation has a present-day temperature of approximately 6.3 Kelvin. Additionally, please select the option from the given choices that you believe is closest to the correct answer!

A. 3931.9 kelvin
B. 4523.6 kelvin
C. 3749.1 kelvin
D. 6936.3 kelvin

Answer:
gpt_response:
To calculate the temperature of the universe at an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, we can use the formula for the temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation as a function of time:

T = To / (√t/t0)

Where:
T = Temperature of the universe at time t
To = Present-day temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation (6.3 Kelvin)
t = Age of the universe (380,000 years after the Big Bang)
t0 = Present age of the universe

Plugging in the values, we get:

T = 6.3 / (√380,000/13.8x10^9)

T = 6.3 / (√0.0275)

T = 6.3 / 0.1657

T ≈ 38.01 Kelvin

Therefore, the closest option from the given choices is C. 3749.1 kelvin.
solution_prompt:
Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to ['D']?: To calculate the temperature of the universe at an age of 380,000 years after the Big Bang, we can use the formula for the temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation as a function of time:

T = To / (√t/t0)

Where:
T = Temperature of the universe at time t
To = Present-day temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation (6.3 Kelvin)
t = Age of the universe (380,000 years after the Big Bang)
t0 = Present age of the universe

Plugging in the values, we get:

T = 6.3 / (√380,000/13.8x10^9)

T = 6.3 / (√0.0275)

T = 6.3 / 0.1657

T ≈ 38.01 Kelvin

Therefore, the closest option from the given choices is C. 3749.1 kelvin.
